pullRequest.body:
This PR is the first in a series that attempts to improve generality in the current API for matrix rank. 

At the moment, for `A : Matrix m n R`, the term `A.rank` is only well-defined for `Fintype n` and `CommRing R`. This is because the definition is in terms of `MulVecLin`, which requires these typeclass assumptions. The `Fintype` assumption, especially, is a little unfortunate, since it necessitates unnecessary and column/row-asymmetric `Fintype` assumptions throughout the API, and makes it impossible to state the important lemma `rank_transpose` for infinite matrices. 

We don't touch the current definition `Matrix.rank` directly here, but we introduce cardinal and ENat-valued notions of rank for infinite matrices, with basic API for monotonicity. The lemma `cRank_toNat_eq_rank` is a proof of concept - it shows that the current `Matrix.rank` could easily be redefined as `Matrix.rank A := (Matrix.cRank A).toNat` with a strict gain in generality, and no loss to the existing API. The plan is to do this, and thereby prove `rank_transpose` in greater generality, in coming PRs. 

The definition `Matrix.eRank` is  also natural, since `Matrix.eRank_transpose` will be true, but `Matrix.cRank_transpose` will not. 

[Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2322226.20Infinite.20matrix.20rank)

---

nodes.body:
### PR summary [4545dcf9ce](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22226/commits/4545dcf9ce9a58b55f67322094b94dd119d7e5b1)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ cRank`
`+ cRank_diagonal`
`+ cRank_le_card_height`
`+ cRank_le_card_width`
`+ cRank_one`
`+ cRank_reindex`
`+ cRank_submatrix`
`+ cRank_submatrix_le`
`+ cRank_toNat_eq_finrank`
`+ cRank_toNat_eq_rank`
`+ cRank_zero`
`+ eRank`
`+ eRank_diagonal`
`+ eRank_le_card_height`
`+ eRank_le_card_width`
`+ eRank_one`
`+ eRank_reindex`
`+ eRank_submatrix`
`+ eRank_submatrix_le`
`+ eRank_toNat_eq_finrank`
`+ eRank_toNat_eq_rank`
`+ eRank_zero`
`+ lift_cRank_reindex`
`+ lift_cRank_submatrix`
`+ lift_cRank_submatrix_le`
`+ linearIndependent_single_ne_zero`
`+ linearIndependent_single_one`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Happy to do that!

> If we're going to triplicate the number of definitions here, I think we should do our best to provide the same API for all of them.
> 
> Obviously you can't do that easily for the `mul` stuff because of how those are finitary, but it would be good to have `rank_zero`, `rank_one`, `rank_diagonal`, and `rank_reindex` for the new spellings. I would guess those are straightforward, so I would prefer to see them as part of this PR.

This is now done. The `diagonal` and `one` lemmas needed some new API showing that families coming from `Pi.single` are linearly independent under appropriate conditions (the existing lemma `Pi.linearIndependent_single` is stated in terms of sigma-types and is cumbersome to use directly, and the simplified versions required finiteness so won't work for this). So I added those. 

I also generalized the two existing reindex/submatrix lemmas for `rank` to not require square matrices. The `Fintype` assumptions can't be removed with the current definition, but easily could if `rank` were redefined in terms of `cRank`.

If we're going to triplicate the number of definitions here, I think we should do our best to provide the same API for all of them.

Obviously you can't do that easily for the `mul` stuff because of how those are finitary, but it would be good to have `rank_zero`, `rank_one`, `rank_diagonal`, and `rank_reindex` for the new spellings. I would guess those are straightforward, so I would prefer to see them as part of this PR.

If we're going to triplicate the number of definitions here, I think we should do our best to provide the same API for all of them.

Obviously you can't do that easily for the `mul` stuff because of how those are finitary, but it would be good to have `rank_zero`, `rank_one`, `rank_diagonal`, and `rank_reindex` for the new spellings. I would guess those are straightforward, so I would prefer to see them as part of this PR.

I'd argue you should drop the `row` and `col` versions(by inlining them into the proof, perhaps via a `calc`), since as soon as you prove `eRank_mono` they are useful.

This should probably be called `eRank_submatrix_le`

```suggestion
noncomputable def cRank (A : Matrix m n R) : Cardinal :=
```
you already have this assumption above.

Is it possible to unify these, giving a `cRank_submatrix_le` where you look at `A.submatrix r c` at once? I see that this is done for `eRank` below, so I expect there is some obstruction, but I don't understand what it is...

I think we should have:
*  `lift_cRank_submatrix_le` (with fully general universes)
*  `cRank_submatrix_le` (with partial universe monomorphism, which is enough for `id` in the row)

I did try this, and got frustrated by the universe issues in the full generality of the submatrix statement, let alone the proof - there are types on five universes involved. I can have another go, but could possibly use some help.
Do we still need to go via the `id` versions here now that the cRank version is generalized?
Please delete this lemma (or rather, inline it below), it is strictly less general than `cRank_submatrix_le`.
Sorry, thought I had.

```suggestion
    lift.{um} (A.submatrix r c).cRank  lift.{um} A.cRank := by
```
you only have to provide the first universe argument to lift, the second is always determined by its argument
Nice, not sure how I missed this proof!

Perhaps
```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem toNat_cRank (A : Matrix m n R) : A.cRank.toNat = A.rank := by
```
and similary for the `eNat` version.

```suggestion
/-- A special case of `lift_cRank_submatrix_le` for when `m` and `m` are in the same universe. -/
```

This doesn't match `rank_le_card_width` further down the file.

I think `card_row` is misleading, since the cardinality of a row could be interepreted as the number of columns!

If you really do feel this new name is better, then please:
* Explain why in the PR description
* Rename and deprecate the `rank` lemmas using the old convention
Good point. Will change it after kid bedtime.
In keeping with the `rank` lemmas below, could you add the equality version for when `r` and `c` are `Equiv`s?

pullRequest.title: feat(Matrix): rank of infinite matrices
